reasoning: The critique targets a meaningful piece of the author’s case for relatively weak compute bottlenecks—specifically the “max speed implied by econ ρ is implausibly low, so ρ must be nearer 0” move—which the author uses to justify a key quantitative range (−0.2<ρ<0). However, the position also offers several other, partly independent reasons to doubt applying economy-wide CES estimates to AI R&D, so refuting this point wouldn’t fully collapse the overall argument (moderate centrality). The critique’s core objection is conceptually strong: if AI R&D is dominated by a sequential, compute-time critical path, then unlimited cognitive labor cannot yield large wall-clock acceleration under fixed compute, undermining the max-speed intuition. But it mostly provides a plausible counter-model rather than evidence that AI R&D actually has such a tight critical path or that the ceiling would be as low as 2–5× (moderate strength). The technical claims about sequential runtime limits are largely correct, with speculative quantitative bounds flagged as illustrative. It is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little to no filler.
title: Sequential dependencies in AI R&D may cap speedup below the paper's assumed range
